title: Tower of London Ghosts: Nine Centuries of the Restless Dead
content:
The Tower has served as palace, prison, and execution ground. Its ghosts include two murdered princes, multiple beheaded queens, and a spectral bear.

This article is part of our comprehensive London ghost tours guide. Whether you're planning a visit or researching from afar, these stories reveal a side of London most visitors never see.

Haunted Foundations: The Tower’s History and Its Deaths

The Tower of London began as the White Tower, ordered by William the Conqueror around 1078. Over nine centuries it has been a royal residence, armory, treasury, menagerie, and, most notoriously, a prison and place of execution. The complex on Tower Hill sits at the junction of the City of London and the River Thames; its postal address is Tower of London, Tower Hill, London EC3N 4AB. That long, public record of confinement and capital punishment supplies the Tower with a distinctly macabre provenance that feeds both historical study and ghost lore.

Executions within the Tower precincts — particularly those on Tower Green and by the scaffold outside the fortress walls — produced names that recur in ghost stories: Anne Boleyn (executed 19 May 1536), Catherine Howard (13 February 1542), Lady Jane Grey (executed on 12 February 1554, often cited as 1554 in contemporary accounts), and others whose remains are said to rest in the Chapel of St Peter ad Vincula. The disappeared Princes in the Tower, Edward V and his brother Richard of Shrewsbury (confined in 1483), provide another unresolved tragedy that lingers in public imagination. These verifiable facts anchor the Tower’s spectral narratives in specific dates, places, and people, so when witnesses claim apparitions or unaccountable sounds, listeners can link those claims to clear historical events.

Because of the Tower’s high profile and dense documentation, the site attracts both careful historians and folklorists. Researchers treating the Tower as a London ghost locale emphasize the difference between documented history and oral tradition: the former supplies names and dates; the latter supplies the voices, footsteps, and apparitions that people report. The two strands — record and memory — entwine in eyewitness accounts and investigator reports, making the Tower one of the United Kingdom’s most persistent London haunted sites in both academic and popular registers.

The Major Phantoms: Anne Boleyn, the Princes, and Lady Jane Grey

Certain figures loom larger in Tower folklore than others. Anne Boleyn is perhaps the Tower’s most celebrated phantom: her execution on 19 May 1536 at the command of Henry VIII left a public image of a headless queen. Since at least the 18th century, visitors and guards have reported seeing a lady in white or the silhouette of a woman carrying her head near the site of the scaffold and the Chapel of St Peter ad Vincula, where Anne is buried. While historians chart Anne’s political fall and execution with documentary sources, folklore preserves the image of a restless presence tied to a sudden, violent death.

The case of the Princes in the Tower — Edward V (born 2 November 1470) and Richard of Shrewsbury (born 17 August 1473) — supplies another recurring apparition motif. The two boys disappeared in 1483 after being lodged in the Tower by their uncle, Richard, Duke of Gloucester, who became Richard III. The facts are contested; the boys’ ultimate fate remains unresolved in the historical record. Stories that include ghostly children crying in the Bloody Tower or fleeting childlike figures visible from the windows link spectral narrative to a still-open question of historical responsibility. Such stories typically refer to specific locations — the Bloody Tower and its windows — making them spatially precise London ghost claims.

Lady Jane Grey’s short reign and execution (12 February 1554) also generate spectral reports. As a young woman who briefly held the crown and suffered a politically driven death, she is often invoked in accounts of a pale woman or phantom in the garden areas close to the Chapel and the Green. These three protagonists — Anne Boleyn, the Princes, and Lady Jane Grey — form a repertory of Tower phantoms that repeatedly appear in witness statements, guidebooks, and investigative reports, ensuring their continued presence in public imagination about what constitutes a London haunted landmark.

Witness Accounts and Investigations: What People Have Reported

Reported paranormal experiences at the Tower cross a long span of time and vary in detail. Investigators and collectors of folklore note that accounts originate from visitors, Yeoman Warders, museum staff, and organized groups such as the Ghost Club. Peter Underwood, a well-known 20th-century folklorist and ghost investigator, collected and published accounts of spectral activity at the Tower; his work consolidated anecdotal reports that had circulated in local papers and guides. The Ghost Club, an investigative body active since the 19th century, has also recorded observations at the Tower during its inquiries. These organizational sources provide patterns even when individual witness names are absent from published summaries.

Two representative reported incidents illustrate the type of claims that recur. In one widely cited case, a night-shift Yeoman Warder is said to have encountered an apparition in the chapel precincts—an event recorded in several late-20th-century collections of Tower stories. He reportedly felt a “cold presence,” heard muffled footsteps, and saw the outline of a woman leave the burial area of St Peter ad Vincula. In another report, visitors in the Bloody Tower corridor claimed to hear the sound of a child crying despite the area being empty; their account, repeated in guidebook annotations and anthologies, became part of the Tower’s child-ghost lore linked to the Princes. Although these reports often appear without extensive independent corroboration, their recurrence and consistency across multiple witnesses and decades merit attention.

Professional investigators emphasize methodology: establishing timelines, interviewing witnesses, and checking for natural explanations such as structural noises, plumbing, or audio bleed from nearby modern installations. The Tower’s complex architecture — stone floors, narrow stairways, and river winds — can produce auditory and visual anomalies that are later framed as paranormal. Still, when multiple independent witnesses report the same sensory details in the same place, researchers note the pattern and weigh it against environmental and psychological factors.

Strange Phenomena Catalogued: Sounds, Apparitions, and Physical Effects

Reported phenomena at the Tower fall into a few clear categories: apparitions (headless figures, pale women, childlike forms), unexplained sounds (footsteps, sobbing, indistinct voices), sudden drops in temperature, and instances of objects moving or lights behaving strangely. These categories align with common types reported at other historic sites but are anchored here to specific Tower locales: Tower Green, the Chapel of St Peter ad Vincula, the Bloody Tower, and the White Tower. Listing the phenomena with places helps readers and investigators know what to expect or look for in records.

Quick reference (examples):

- Tower Green: Apparitions of executed nobility reported near the spot historically used for private executions (Anne Boleyn, Lady Jane Grey).
- Chapel of St Peter ad Vincula: Cold spots, whispered prayers, and sightings near burial sites.
- Bloody Tower: Childlike cries and fleeting silhouettes attributed to the Princes.
- White Tower & ramparts: Unexplained footsteps and shadowy figures reported by guards and visitors.

Many of these experiences share temporal features: they are most commonly reported at night or in the hours just before dawn; they often occur during periods when the Tower is quiet or when small groups are present. Investigative teams and long-term staff frequently note that these reports spike after media pieces or new guidebook editions draw public attention to specific stories. That pattern suggests a social amplification effect — once a haunting narrative is widely known, new observers may interpret ambiguous sensory data through that narrative lens. Responsible investigation distinguishes between recurrence of reports and independent corroborative evidence such as simultaneous multi-sensor records.

Memory, Politics, and the Making of Legend

Hauntings at the Tower of London do not arise in a cultural vacuum. The Tower’s role in dynastic politics, public punishment, and national myth-making makes it fertile ground for memory-based narratives. Executions were public and politically charged; the Tower’s victims were often symbols in larger struggles over succession and power. Ghost stories serve as a kind of residual rhetoric: they keep contested deaths visible and moralize them outside of formal historical argument. For instance, the tragic image of Anne Boleyn’s headless apparition can function as a commentary on Tudor brutality or as a way to humanize a figure often reduced to political maneuvering.

Folklorists emphasize that the persistence of an apparition narrative depends on repetition in cultural products: guidebooks, pamphlets, newspaper pieces, television programs, and online forums each reproduce and sometimes embellish stories. Political memory also plays a role: as historians reassess responsibility for events like the Princes’ disappearance, ghost lore can shift to reflect present-day sensibilities. In other words, the Tower’s hauntings are not static; they change as living communities reinterpret the past.

Understanding this process helps separate what is socially produced from what might be an anomalous sensory event. That separation does not invalidate witnesses’ experiences; rather, it places them in context. When a Yeoman Warder, a school group, or a dedicated investigator reports a sighting, their description becomes part of the Tower’s evolving cultural archive. Scholars of folklore and public history treat those descriptions as data about how modern London constructs memory, grief, and national narrative around a concrete urban site — a quintessentially London haunted case study.

Visiting the Tower Today: What to See, Where to Look, and How to Think Critically

For those studying the Tower’s reputation as a London ghost site, certain practical details matter. The Tower of London sits at Tower Hill, adjacent to Tower Bridge and the River Thames; the official entrance is on the north side, and the site is managed by Historic Royal Palaces. The precise spots most commonly tied to hauntings are Tower Green (near the private execution spot), the Chapel of St Peter ad Vincula (burial place for many executed nobles), the Bloody Tower (associated with the Princes), and the ramparts and White Tower where guards historically reported odd sensations. Photographs, diaries, and oral testimony collected in museums and archives supplement on-site observation for anyone conducting careful research.

Visitors and researchers should adopt a posture of respectful skepticism. That means recording who saw what and when, checking environmental and structural explanations (old timbers creak, heating and ventilation systems cause drafts and noises), and noting how expectation affects perception. Organizations that investigate historic hauntings often require multiple independent witnesses and, when possible, corroborative data (audio recordings, temperature logs, concurrent eyewitness statements) before attributing an incident to an unknown cause. The Tower’s long, well-documented past means that linking a sensory experience to a historical event can be easier here than at many other sites, but it also increases the likelihood of expectation-driven interpretation.

Finally, the Tower’s role as a living museum and a national monument matters for how reports are handled. The Yeoman Warders and Historic Royal Palaces staff balance public interest in the supernatural with responsibilities to conservation, public safety, and historical accuracy. Whether confronting an unexplained sound in the Bloody Tower or a chill near St Peter ad Vincula, the most useful response combines careful documentation, knowledge of the Tower’s verified history, and openness to the psychological and environmental dimensions of reported phenomena — an approach that does justice to both the site’s real past and its persistent reputation as one of London’s most haunted places.
